Away ye gayer scenes, away,</br>The smiling morn, the garish day;</br>Vanish, thou blazing lamp of light,</br>And bring me black congenial Night.</br>Envelop'd in her gloom, I love</br>Through long resounding ailes to rove:</br>Beneath the dome then lie reclin'd,</br>And feel it tremble to the wind;</br>Hear the wide scatter'd fragments fall</br>From rifted arch, or crumbling wall;</br>While Madness, in fantastic state,</br>Unconscious of impending fate,</br>Beneath the tott'ring ruin sits,</br>And laughs, and weeps, and sings, by fits;</br>Bares to the winds his ghastly form,</br>And courts the horrors of the storm.</br>Ah!  while with devious steps I tread</br>These awful mansions of the dead,</br>What hideous shapes arrest my feet,</br>What beck'ning ghosts my name repeat?</br>They cease; a death-like silence reigns,</br>Freezing the blood within my veins.</br>In this great world am I alone?</br>O!  for some sigh, some dying groan!</br>Ye thunders, roll!  thou firm earth, shake,</br>With any sound this silence break.</br>Hence let me haste:  ah!  whither fly!</br>Horror, Despair, and Death, are nigh,</br>For in yon vale, where baleful yews</br>Drink and retain Night's sickly dews,</br>Where the green pool, begirt with reeds,</br>Half choak'd with matted grass and weeds,</br>Loads the thick air with vapours foul,</br>Where flits the bat, where shrieks the owl,</br>There Suicide, in grim despair,</br>With hurried hand, and frantic air,</br>Grasps first the steel, then poison's bowl,</br>Wildly his fiery eye-balls roll;</br>And now he tears, and bites the ground,</br>While hell-born Furies dance around,</br>His agonies with joy descry,</br>Anxious to hear his parting sigh;</br>Then hurry him to shades below,</br>To unquench'd fire and endless woe.</br>While in yon cavern's depth profound,</br>Whose vaults with clanking chains resound,</br>Of things unclean the dark abode</br>The curling snake, the loathsome toad,</br>Dwells Horror, with a ruffian brood:</br>Lust, Rapine, Murder, drench'd in blood.</br>In heaps the mangled corses lie,</br>The fume of gore ascends on high,</br>The raven pauses on his way,</br>And scents with joy his destin'd prey.</br>What sounds terrific strike mine ear!</br>What shrieks, what dying groans I hear!</br>O!  bear me from such scenes away,</br>And bring me bright congenial day.

Come then, thou nymph of sprightly mien,</br>More beauteous than the Paphian queen,</br>In all thy animated glee,</br>Come blooming, young, Euphrosyne.</br>While Exercise, with sun-burnt face,</br>With nervous limbs, and manly grace,</br>Rous'd by the joy-inspiring hounds,</br>Fearlessly o'er each barrier bounds,</br>Stranger to Discord, Care, and Pain,</br>The happy son of Dian's train,</br>Come, jolly Bacchus, ivy crown'd,</br>And let the sparkling glass go round;</br>With festive dance, and joyous song,</br>Waft the swift-footed hours along.</br>By the dim taper's sickly light,</br>Let the Sage waste the tedious night;</br>And, turning o'er th' historic page,</br>The wisdom glean of ev'ry age:</br>But you, who bask in Pleasure's ray,</br>Live to enjoy the present day;</br>Let dull mortals fear to-morrow,</br>You have nought to do with sorrow,</br>Then let me share your jollity,</br>And follow gay Eurphrosyne.</br>But, ah!  when rosy youth is fled,</br>And Time has silver'd o'er my head,</br>Say, will she then her pow'r display,</br>And gild with joy life's closing day!</br>Ah!  no, she like the world will prove,</br>And shun, when most I need her love.</br>Adieu to all her fleeting charms,</br>A nobler theme my bosom warms.

Come, sober Eve, in meekness drest,</br>Parent of silence, peace, and rest:</br>And then, with eyes uprais'd to Heav'n,</br>With stately pace, sedate and even,</br>Pride of Wisdom, scorn of Folly,</br>Sacred, musing, Melancholy:</br>And thou, sweet songstress of the night,</br>Who shun'st the busy glare of light,</br>O Philomel, thy strains prolong,</br>And calm my sorrows with thy song,</br>For thou, sweet bird, perhaps, like me,</br>Hast felt the pangs of misery;</br>Perhaps, unfriended an forlorn,</br>Hast sigh'd through life's disastrous morn;</br>Mine wore the garb that April wears,</br>A little sunshine, many tears.</br>Here safe within this hallow'd shade,</br>Which forward Guilt dares not invade,</br>With Melancholy let me dwell,</br>And bid the busy world farewell.</br>What though, within this calm retreat,</br>The heart with joy no more may beat,</br>Yet treach'rous Scandal comes not hear,</br>To draw from Beauty's eye the tear,</br>To rend that heart with throbbing woes,</br>Where Truth and Innocence repose.</br>Let the presumptuous sons of Pride</br>My unambitious choice deride;</br>Their gilded domes, that tow'ring rise,</br>I never view with envious eyes.</br>Alone, unseen, I love to rove</br>Through this retir'd umbrageous grove,</br>Where scarcely breathes the whisp'ring wind,</br>And all conspires to fill my mind</br>With meditations calm and holy,</br>Becoming thee, O Melancholy.</br>To thoughts that harrow up the soul,</br>To mirth, impatient of controul,</br>Gladly I bid a last farewell,</br>With thee alone I mean to dwell.</br>Pride of Wisdom, scorn of Folly,</br>Sacred, musing, Melancholy.</br>
